title: Authors and Citation
text: Jeffrey R. Stevens. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stevens J (2023). formatstats: Format Print Statistical Output. https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats, https://jeffreyrstevens.github.io/formatstats/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {formatstats: Format and Print Statistical Output},   author = {Jeffrey R. Stevens},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats, https://jeffreyrstevens.github.io/formatstats/}, }

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: goal formatstats provide functions flexibly format statistical output way can inserted R Markdown documents. analogous apa_print() functions papaja package, functions package can print Markdown LaTeX syntax. output document PDF, doesn’t matter. output document Word document (required many journal publishers), Markdown syntax generates editable output instead image output. default style statistical output follows American Psychological Association style, defaults can -ridden flexibly format output.

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: can install development version formatstats GitHub :

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: example, ’ll create correlation mtcars data set. Now can apply format_corr() function cars_corr create Markdown-formatted character string statistical results. can embed inline R Markdown code generate results.
code: library(formatstats) (cars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp)) #>  #>  Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  mtcars$mpg and mtcars$disp #> t = -8.7472, df = 30, p-value = 9.38e-10 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.9233594 -0.7081376 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.8475514

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (`r format_corr(cars_corr)`).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (r(30) = -0.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], p < .001).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: can also format things like Bayes factors flexibly:

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: cite formatstats, use: Stevens, Jeffrey R. (2023). formatstats: Format print statistical output. (version 0.0.0.9000) https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: Format Bayes factors

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: format_bf(   x,   digits1 = 1,   digits2 = 2,   cutoff = NULL,   italics = TRUE,   subscript = "10",   type = "md" )

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: x Number Bayes factor BayesFactor object digits1 Number digits decimal Bayes factors > 1 digits2 Number digits decimal Bayes factors < 1 cutoff Cutoff using _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> (value must > 1) italics Logical whether BF label italicized subscript Subscript include BF label ("10", "01", "" subscript) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: character string includes BF~10~ Bayes factor formatted Markdown LaTeX. Bayes factor cutoff, _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> used.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: # Format Bayes factors > 1 format_bf(12.4444) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 12.4" # By default, Bayes factors > 1000 will use scientific notation format_bf(1244.44) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.2×10^3^" # Control digits for Bayes factors > 1 with digits1 format_bf(1244.44, digits1 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.244×10^3^" # Control cutoff for scientific notation with cutoff format_bf(1244.44, cutoff = 10000) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1244.4" # Format Bayes factors < 1 format_bf(0.111) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.11" # By default, Bayes factors <_0.001 will use scientific notation format_bf(0.0001) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.0×10^-4^" # Control digits for Bayes factors < 1 with digits2 format_bf(0.111, digits2 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.111" # Control cutoff for scientific notation with cutoff format_bf(0.001, cutoff = 100) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ < 0.01"

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: Format correlation statistics

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: format_corr(   x,   digits = 2,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   ci = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   dfs = "par",   type = "md" )

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: x Correlation object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, correlation coefficients pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values ci Logical indicator whether print 95% confidence intervals italics Logical whether p label italicized dfs Formatting degrees freedom ("par" = parenthetical, "sub" = subscript, "none" = print degrees freedom) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: # Prepare data mtcars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp) # Print statistics format_corr(mtcars_corr) #> [1] "_r_(30) = -0.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], _p_ < .001" # Change digits format_corr(mtcars_corr, digits = 3) #> [1] "_r_(30) = -0.848, 95% CI [-0.923, -0.708], _p_ < .001" # Change cutoff digits for p-value format_corr(mtcars_corr, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_r_(30) = -0.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], _p_ < .01" # Add leading zero to p-value and don't print confidence intervals format_corr(mtcars_corr, pzero = TRUE, ci = FALSE) #> [1] "_r_(30) = -0.85, _p_ < 0.001"

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: Format numbers

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: character string formatting number specified number digits decimal.

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: Format p-values

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: format_p(x, pdigits = 3, pzero = FALSE, italics = TRUE, type = "md")

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: x Number representing p-value pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values italics Logical whether p label italicized type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: character string includes p p-value formatted Markdown LaTeX. p-value pdigits cutoff, _p_ < <cutoff> used.

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: format_p(0.001) #> [1] "_p_ = .001" # Round digits for p-values greater than cutoff format_p(0.111, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ = .11" # Default cutoff is p < 0.001 format_p(0.0001) #> [1] "_p_ < .001" # Set cutoff with pdigits format_p(0.0001, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ < .01" # Include leading zero format_p(0.001, pzero = TRUE) #> [1] "_p_ = 0.001"

what: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: Format numbers scientific notation

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: character string number scientific notation formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
code: format_scientific(1111) #> [1] "1.1×10^3^" # Control number of digits after decimal with digits format_scientific(1111, digits = 3) #> [1] "1.111×10^3^"

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: Format t-test statistics

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: format_ttest(   x,   digits = 1,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   full = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   dfs = "par",   mean = "abbr",   type = "md" )

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: x t-test object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, t-statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values full Logical indicator whether include means confidence intervals just t-statistic p-value italics Logical whether p label italicized dfs Formatting degrees freedom ("par" = parenthetical, "sub" = subscript, "none" = print degrees freedom) mean Formatting mean label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: # Prepare data mtcars_tt <- t.test(formula = mtcars$mpg ~ mtcars$vs) # Print statistics format_ttest(mtcars_tt) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.9, 95% CI [-11.5, -4.4], _t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < .001" # Change digits format_ttest(mtcars_tt, digits = 2) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.94, 95% CI [-11.46, -4.42], _t_(22.72) = -4.67, _p_ < .001" # Change cutoff digits for p-value format_ttest(mtcars_tt, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.9, 95% CI [-11.5, -4.4], _t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < .01" # Add leading zero to p-value and don't print confidence intervals format_ttest(mtcars_tt, pzero = TRUE, full = FALSE) #> [1] "_t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < 0.001"
